TopicTitle: [0.23.5] Soviet Soyuz Rocketfamily v2.4 (13.May - Russian Tulip and more)

Articles.Content: I had no idea about the 7K. I can see the resemblance!
well ... here something from me for a Soyuz with 3 Kerbakls somewhere inside. it has no retrorockets BUT a nice detachable Heatshild ^^
Mine doesn't have retrorockets either. Maybe I should add some. And solar panels...

Mine's the only one with retro rockets!

...and a orbital module that can hold crew!

tell me please, what did you do to get the radial fuel tanks?where does from NP,those vernier-ish thingys or something completely else?Or did you made the rocket up with SRBs?

EDIT:reffering to the Proton pic ofc
Some nice work, glad to see you giving credit to those that inspired you

Mine's the only one with retro rockets!

...and a orbital module that can hold crew!

Guess again, Jack!

EDIT:

I have encountered a major problem with my Soyuz: the orbiter section breaks off when docking to another craft. I need to change the way it's attached.

EDIT 2: It's more serious than I thought. The hacky way that I arranged the capsules makes it impossible to handle the torque from docking. This will require a major overhaul.

Edited May 10, 2013 by GusTurbo

Here's my attempt at the Soyuz Spacecraft (100% stock):

Craft file here: http://www./?ilwz3uglw7h8qcl

Orbital and service modules detach for reentry, antennae deploy with the panels via action group 1.

I made a Soyuz rocket to carry it, but it uses some Fairing Factory parts. I'm working on making it 100% stock currently.

Here it is currently. Looks a little short to me, but that can be fixed of course:

Bonus Korolev cross:

Edited May 14, 2013 by ethan829
This is awesome! Thanks for reviving this thread.

Correction, the R-7 Semyorka ICBM WAs the first Inter Continental Ballistic Missle but was not the first to be outfitted with a nuclear payload. The first ICBM outfitted with a nuclear payload was the SM-65 Atlas which was a dry hydrogen paylaod. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SM-65_Atlas

Small update. I've made "Progress" since my last post...I'll show myself out.

Carries extra fuel where the descent module would be. Sections don't separate, and are all discarded after the mission is complete.

@ baarnold: thx for the info

@ethan829: cool looking Soyuz, where do you got the fairings?

@ all : sry for beeing away, but you know university can be troublsome

edit: getting back into Kerbal, i did a little tribute to Mulbin: a soft cuddling of his Soyuzcarft and mine over the oceans of Kerbin.

Great picture! a proper family shot of the father and son of the KSP soyuz My next Muna-LK will take some influence from the updates in this thread.

Let's keep this family photo album rolling. Here's my craft docked with Giggleplex's.

Edited May 19, 2013 by GusTurbo

hey Gusturbo, i took your idea of a bigsize Soyuzrocket and worked on it ... still working on the wobble-of-death. it has the right amount of fuel and .. ,technicaly, enough trust in the third stage. lot's of things to do, until i can release a download for teh craftfile ^^

edit: over550 parts so far ... -.-" my PC is loving me XD
Looks cool. What does the center of the lower stage look like without the boosters? My design kind of sacrificed accuracy in that regard, since the core of my lower stage is 2.5m.

hey Gusturbo, i took your idea of a bigsize Soyuzrocket and worked on it ... still working on the wobble-of-death.

Have you tried setting up a hotkey to turn off the gimbals on most of your engines? That's how I reduced wobble on the Jool V.

Let's keep this family photo album rolling. Here's my craft docked with Giggleplex's.

LOL my gigantic 7K.
Now I just need to make an adapter to dock to the minis.

an adapter? no problem i have one

and you ask for detaisl for my try for teh big Soyuz, here a pciture in the VAB with only one booster attached. all struts have been removed. i'm still working on the freaking death-wobble ... first and second stage are going to be solid like a rock, but the coupler to teh third stage is makeing trouble ...
Ah, looking good. Do you have the struts like the real thing at the bottom? Those really helped on my design.

I took a crack at the tapered lower stage. It required a slight redesign to my boosters, but I like how it turned out.

On the pad:

Boosters jettisoned:

Comparison with the old booster design:

Interestingly, even though my new booster is right up against the side of the core, and possibly clipping, it doesn't cause any problems.
